newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee reverses as rally loses steam.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee reverses as rally loses steam.

text.p: LIFFE coffee futures reversed direction to end in the minus column after a stunning week-long rally in the run-up to a key producer meeting in Brazil lost steam.
Traders said the retracement was also seen as a technical correction to the well overbought condition in the market which saw a jump of 21 percent in four days.

The market took off higher as speculators bought on the back of overnight news the Association of Coffee Producing Countries (ACPC) would limit exports by a further 1.3 million 60-kg bags between January and June.
The early buying drove the March contract to just above the $1,600 mark.
"Its failure to hold above $1,600 and then New York's failure to move high led to sell stops in London," said one.
Coupled with pre-weekend profit-taking, the decline gradually gathered momentum and the second-month contract finished $50 down at $1,520 a tonne after ranging within a large $98 band.
The day's volume reached a modest 8,834 lots.
The ACPC export cut was announced after a meeting in Brazil late on Thursday. Some traders viewed it as constructive although it fell short of a previously-stated goal of 2.5 million bag reduction.

"It will certainly help robusta producers get better prices," said one. But they warned that the plan which would involve a cut of 1.0 million bags of robustas and 300,000 bags of arabica could be undermined by non-members.
"So far the ACPC has succeeded in reducing consumer stocks and if they succeed in restricting exports, the market can be in their hands," the trader added.
But despite the dramatic increase in robusta values, its price differential to the premium arabica coffee gapped wider to 68 U.S. cents a lb basis March.
Thursday's positive ACPC news was partly overshadowed by reports that dockworkers at a major Colombian coffee port had ended their prolonged strike.
